articles.title: Scientists want to prevent AI from going rogue by teaching it to be bad first
articles.summary: Researchers are trying to “vaccinate” artificial intelligence systems against developing evil, overly flattering or otherwise harmful personality traits in a seemingly counterintuitive way: by giving them a small dose of those problematic traits.
articles.translated_title: Scientists want to prevent AI from going rogue by teaching it to be bad first
articles.translated_summary: Researchers are trying to “vaccinate” artificial intelligence systems against developing evil, overly flattering or otherwise harmful personality traits in a seemingly counterintuitive way: by giving them a small dose of those problematic traits.

articles.title: Japan tech giant SoftBank Group sees better fortunes on surging AI stocks
articles.summary: Japanese technology conglomerate SoftBank Group has reported a $2.9 billion profit for the April-June quarter, rebounding from a loss a year earlier, as its investments benefited from the craze for artificial intelligence.
articles.translated_title: Japan tech giant SoftBank Group sees better fortunes on surging AI stocks

articles.title: Google Pledges $1 Billion For AI Training At US Universities, Aims To Expand Globally
articles.summary: In a strategic move, Alphabet Inc (NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG) subsidiary Google has committed $1 billion to provide artificial intelligence (AI) offering educational resources and technical assistance to U.S. colleges and nonprofits.
articles.translated_title: Google Pledges $1 Billion For AI Training At US Universities, Aims To Expand Globally

articles.title: SoftBank Swings to Profit on Vision Fund Gains Ahead of AI Push
articles.summary: SoftBank Group Corp. swung to a bigger-than-expected profit in the June quarter, riding on gains from its bets on Nvidia Corp. and startups in a boost for founder Masayoshi Son’s bets on artificial intelligence technologies.
articles.translated_title: SoftBank Swings to Profit on Vision Fund Gains Ahead of AI Push

articles.title: AI Helps Rapidly Crack Yearlong Mystery in Alps
articles.summary: The search for the body of a hiker who vanished in Italy's Alps last September ended up being a remarkably quick one, thanks to artificial intelligence. The National Alpine...

articles.title: Google to spend $1 billion on AI education and job training in the U.S.
articles.summary: Google is partnering with colleges to give students free access to its artificial intelligence tools.
articles.translated_title: Google to spend $1 billion on AI education and job training in the U.S.

articles.title: Former Tesla Leaders Start AI-Focused Automotive Company
articles.summary: Former leaders of Tesla Inc.’s supercomputer program have started a new artificial intelligence company focused on data center services for industries from automotive to robotics, according to people familiar with the matter.

articles.title: Researchers hacked Google Gemini to take control of a smart home
articles.summary: Cybersecurity researchers were able to control smart home devices by hacking the Google Gemini artificial intelligence assistant.
articles.translated_title: Researchers hacked Google Gemini to take control of a smart home
articles.translated_summary: Cybersecurity researchers were able to control smart home devices by hacking the Google Gemini artificial intelligence assistant.

articles.title: Can US Become Robotics Capital of the World?
articles.summary: White House artificial intelligence and crypto czar David Sacks is today but one of many who believe that America and much of the world will soon fall in love with actual robots that assist them in chores from folding laundry — as Tesla's Optimus apparently can already do — to taking out the trash, washing dishes, and performing other household chores. Robotic machines already are performing major functions in fields from manufacturing to land mine and bomb removal.

articles.title: How DeepSeek and Open-Source Models Are Shaking Up AI
articles.summary: Tech companies and academics have long wrestled with the risks and rewards of building open-source software. But the frenzy around generative artificial intelligence has lent new significance to the debate.
